subtitle: How can I help
title: Female genital mutilation
content:
My name is Loyok Jane, I live in Mbale. Back in my village, female genital mutilation (FGM) is rampant. Last week, my cousin Agnes aged 11 years ran away from our village in Kapchorwa and is now living with me. She said she was being forced to undergo FGM so she ran away. I want to know how I can help her. 

**What the Law Says:**

"Uganda is one of the few countries around the world that have outlawed Female Genital Mutilation (FGM). Female genital mutilation is practiced by 1% of Uganda’s population namely the Sabiny, Pokot, Tepetha and Kadam. Among the Pokot, FGM/C is nearly universal at 95 per cent (95%) and is 50 per cent (50%) among the Sabiny. Up to 134,000 women are affected.  In 2010, the Government came up with a law called the Prohibition of Female Genital Mutilation Act which prohibited this practice and provides for a punishment of imprisonment of up to 10 years for those involved in it.
The practice therefore by members of the community who wish to carry out FGM is unlawful and could get them imprisoned for up to 10 years.

**Possible Solutions:**
		
"Uganda is one of the few countries around the world that have outlawed Female Genital Mutilation (FGM). Female genital mutilation is practiced by 1% of Uganda’s population namely the Sabiny, Pokot, Tepetha and Kadam. Among the Pokot, FGM/C is nearly universal at 95 per cent (95%) and is 50 per cent (50%) among the Sabiny. Up to 134,000 women are affected.  In 2010, the Government came up with a law called the Prohibition of Female Genital Mutilation Act which prohibited this practice and provides for a punishment of imprisonment of up to 10 years for those involved in it.
The practice therefore by members of the community who wish to carry out FGM is unlawful and could get them imprisoned for up to 10 years.

"
